description:
One day, high-school student Koyomi Araragi catches a girl named Hitagi Senjougahara when she trips. But—much to his surprise—she doesn’t weigh anything. At all. She says an encounter with a so-called “crab” took away all her weight …

Monsters have been here since the beginning.
Always.
Everywhere.

(Source: Kodansha USA)
synonyms: ปกรณัมของเหล่าภูต

tags.name: Urban Fantasy
tags.description: Set in a world similar to the real world, but with the existence of magic or other supernatural elements.

tags.name: Youkai
tags.description: Prominently features supernatural creatures from Japanese folklore.

tags.name: Vampire
tags.description: Prominently features a character who is a vampire.

tags.name: Male Protagonist
tags.description: Main character is male.

tags.name: Primarily Female Cast
tags.description: Main cast is mostly composed of female characters.

tags.name: Primarily Teen Cast
tags.description: Main cast is mostly composed of teen characters.

tags.name: Philosophy
tags.description: Relating or devoted to the study of the fundamental nature of knowledge, reality, and existence.

tags.name: Heterosexual
tags.description: Prominently features a romance between a man and a woman, not inherently sexual.

tags.name: Meta
tags.description: Features fourth wall-breaking references to itself or genre tropes.

tags.name: Gods
tags.description: Prominently features a character of divine or religious nature.

tags.name: Female Harem
tags.description: Main cast features the protagonist plus several female characters who are romantically interested in them.

tags.name: Ghost
tags.description: Prominently features a character who is a ghost.

tags.name: Tragedy
tags.description: Centers around tragic events and unhappy endings.

tags.name: Denpa
tags.description: Works that feature themes of social dissociation, delusions, and other issues like suicide, bullying, self-isolation, paranoia, and technological necessity in daily lives. Classic iconography: telephone poles, rooftops, and trains.

tags.name: Surreal Comedy
tags.description: Prominently features comedic moments that defy casual reasoning, resulting in illogical events.

tags.name: Love Triangle
tags.description: Centered around romantic feelings between more than two people. Includes all love polygons.

tags.name: Nekomimi
tags.description: Humanoid characters with cat-like features such as cat ears and a tail.

tags.name: Nudity
tags.description: Features a character wearing no clothing or exposing intimate body parts.

tags.name: Tomboy
tags.description: Features a girl who exhibits characteristics or behaviors considered in many cultures to be typical of boys.

tags.name: Dissociative Identities
tags.description: A case where one or more people share the same body.

tags.name: Gore
tags.description: Prominently features graphic bloodshed and violence.

tags.name: Shounen
tags.description: Target demographic is teenage and young adult males.

tags.name: Monster Girl
tags.description: Prominently features a female character who is part-monster.

tags.name: Body Horror
tags.description: Features characters who undergo horrific transformations or disfigurement, often to their own detriment.

tags.name: School
tags.description: Partly or completely set in a primary or secondary educational institution.

tags.name: Age Regression
tags.description: Prominently features a character who was returned to a younger state.

title.native: 化物語アニメコンプリートガイドブック

alternative: Kiss-Shot Acerola-Orion Heart-Under-Blade (キスショット・アセロラオリオン・ハートアンダーブレード)
Tekketsu ni shite Nekketsu ni shite Reiketsu no Kyuuketsuki (鉄血にして熱血にして冷血の吸血鬼)

node.description:
[Website](http://ni.siois.in) | [Twitter](https://twitter.com/NISIOISIN_info)

NISIOISIN, whose pen name is a palindrome, is a Japanese novelist and manga writer. He attended and left Ritsumeikan University without graduating. In 2002, he debuted with the novel _Kubikiri Cycle_, which earned him the 23rd Mephisto Award at 20 years of age. 

He currently works for Kodansha on Pandora, the Kodansha Box magazine, and Faust, a literary magazine containing the works of other young authors who similarly take influence from light novels and otaku culture. He was also publishing a 12-volume series over 12 months for the Kodansha Box line; fellow author Ryusui Seiryoin was matching this output, and the Kodansha Box website stated that this is the first time in the world two authors have written 12-volume monthly novel series simultaneously for the same publisher.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/VOFAN_TW) | [Pixiv](https://www.pixiv.net/member.php?id=51536) | [Flickr](https://www.flickr.com/photos/vofan/) | [Facebook](https://www.facebook.com/vofanart/) | [YouTube](https://www.youtube.com/@VOFAN_TW)

A Taiwanese illustrator most known for drawing the covers of the Monogatari series and the Boukyaku Tantei series. He speaks Taiwanese, Chinese, Japanese, and English. His name means "Virtual On fan."

__Associated Names:__ Poyoyon Rock (ぽよよんろっく), Poyoyon♥Rock (ぽよよん♥ろっく), Pucchin Purin

[Twitter (NSFW)](https://twitter.com/punipoyo)

A Japanese animator, character designer, and animation director currently living in Tokyo, Japan. He often goes by the pseudonym Poyoyon Rock.  He is also a member of the doujinshi circle Pokopii.  

(Source: Wikipedia)

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/negi_haruba)

Negi Haruba graduated from the manga department of Trident College of Design in 2013. He won an award in the 89th Weekly Shounen Magazine Newcomer Manga Award organized by Kodansha with the one-shot manga *Coward Cross World*. The work was published in Magazine SPECIAL 2013 as his debut.

In 2014, he won a Gold Award for the one-shot *Ura Sekai Communication* in the 21st Dengeki Grand Prize sponsored by KADOKAWA and ASCII Media Works. This work was later published in Weekly Comic Dengeki Daioh magazine in September 2014.

On January 25, 2017, wrote yet another one-shot, titled *5-toubun no Hanayome*. Receiving positive responses for his work, an official serialization of the one-shot was announced and published in Weekly Shounen Magazine on August 9, 2017. A year later, the manga series was announced to get an anime adaptation on August 8, 2018, and to be aired on TBS from January 1, 2019. A second season started airing January 8, 2021.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/KenAkamatsu) | [Website](http://www.ailove.net/main.html) | [Blog](https://kenakamatsu.hatenablog.com/) | [Facebook](https://www.facebook.com/Akamatsu.Ken) | [Tumblr](https://kenakamatsu.tumblr.com/)

Ken Akamatsu is a Japanese mangaka from Tokyo.   

In his teenage years, Akamatsu failed the entrance exam to Tokyo University, and applied for Film Study instead (it is speculated that this is where he got the idea for Love Hina). Eventually, he became famous as an illustrator featured in Comiket (short for Comic Market, a comic convention bi-annually held in Japan). He used the pen name Awa Mizuno (水野亜和). Akamatsu, still in college, then proceeded to win the Weekly Shonen Magazine award twice. His "A Kid's Game for One Summer" was awarded the coveted 50th Shonen Magazine Newcomer's Award soon after he graduated.    

After a big hit with A.I. Love You, he finally made a grand success with his new manga, Love Hina. The series appeared in Weekly Shonen Magazine and has been collected in eleven volumes (with fourteen volumes in total), which have sold over 6 million copies in Japan, and received the Kodansha Manga Award for shōnen in 2001.  Akamatsu had added elements of his own life experiences to the story, and this was said to have induced a unique feeling to the manga especially for Western readers, whose lack of familiarity with Japanese culture for the most part added to the effect. The series, published in America in 2002, was especially well received in many overseas countries - Akamatsu was surprised that even foreign readers found Love Hina to be "cute" and to their liking.    

He is now married to his wife 'Kanon' Akamatsu, who was previously a singer/idol.

Since 2022, he has held a seat in the House of Councillors proportional representation block of the National Diet.

__[Twitter](https://twitter.com/hiro_mashima)__ | __[YouTube](https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCQLYbIvGWtClestisnB1_6A)__

Japanese manga artist most known for his manga Groove Adventure Rave, published by Kodansha's Weekly Shonen Magazine, from 1999 to 2005. The series was later adapted into an anime. However, the anime adaption was cancelled before it could complete the series.

In 2003, he collected some of his one-shot titles in two volumes: Mashima-en- Vol.1 & 2. Those stories include, among others, Cocona, "Xmas Hearts" and "Fairy Tail", a sort of prototype for his last work.

In 2006, he began his now finished series, Fairy Tail, serialized in Kodansha's Weekly Shonen Magazine. He also published the manga Monster Hunter Orage.

Hiro Mashima was a notable guest at the 2008 San Diego Comic-Con. He has one daughter.

His artwork and [Oda Eiichiro](https://anilist.co/staff/96881/EiichiroOda)'s are greatly similar, but that is due to both of them being influenced largely by [Toriyama Akira](https://anilist.co/staff/96901/AkiraToriyama)'s work growing up.

His former assistant was [Yoshikawa Miki](https://anilist.co/staff/98703/MikiYoshikawa) author of Yankee-kun to Megane-chan.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/Atsushi_Ohkubo) | [Official Website](http://ameblo.jp/atsushi-ohkubo/) | [YouTube](https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCSYlewtVNXpHDw24YYP-Gzw)

He was the assistant of [Rando Ayamine](https://anilist.co/staff/96887/Rando-Ayamine) on the manga series [GetBackers](https://anilist.co/anime/132/GetBackers/).
[Yoshiki Tonogai](https://anilist.co/staff/97918/Yoshiki-Tonogai), [Takuji Katou](https://anilist.co/staff/99906/Takuji-Katou), [Takatoshi Shiozawa](https://anilist.co/staff/100604/Takatoshi-Shiozawa), [Tomoyuki Maru](https://anilist.co/staff/106881/Maru-Tomoyuki), and [Kei Urana](https://anilist.co/staff/263766/Kei-Urana) were once assistants.

Yousuke is a manga artist best known as the author of [Boarding School Juliet](https://anilist.co/manga/86279/Kishuku-Gakkou-no-Juliet/).

He graduated from Osaka University of Arts in the Character Art and Design department. Later he started working as an assistant to [Shizumu Watanabe](https://anilist.co/staff/107131/Shizumu-Watanabe) before starting on his own manga [Seiten High School Idol-Bu!](https://anilist.co/manga/122266/Seiten-Koukou-Idol-Bu-/).

During this time, he would use scenes from works such as [Suzumiya Haruhi](https://anilist.co/anime/849/Suzumiya-Haruhi-no-Yuuutsu/) to practice his drawing by analyzing them and drawing them from different angles.

In 2010, Yousuke received an honorable mention with his oneshot work "Iceberg" (氷山) in Weekly Shonen Jump's 84th Newcomer Award.

Yousuke's first child was born on August 18, 2020. On August 25, 2020, he announced on social media that he had become a father.

[Website](http://napaou.blog.fc2.com/) | [Twitter](https://twitter.com/yousukekaneda) | [Pixiv](https://www.pixiv.net/en/users/3628803)

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/seokouji)

Seo Kouji is a Japanese manga creator from Shobara, Hiroshima, Japan. He has stated in an interview that he was a member of his high school's track and field team and that he loves to watch baseball both emphasized in his hit manga Suzuka. He debuted in 1996 with the one-shot "Half & Half" in Fresh magazine. His two hits, Suzuka and Cross Over, both mixed the genres of sports with high school romance. Suzuka focused on track and field while Cross Over used basketball. It is also interesting to note that the main love interest of the male protagonists of several of his works are extremely similar in appearance, namely in Half and Half, Cross Over, Suzuka, and Kimi No Iru Machi. Seo was an assistant to Oushima Tsukasa, and studied under Fujio Fujiko and Soda Masahito.  In 2009 Seo designed the High School Girl Kimchi for Hokubi Construction food company.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/yoshikawamiki)

Miki Yoshikawa is a Japanese manga artist. Her debut work was a one-shot called Glory Days in Kodansha's Magazine Special. She was previously [Hiro Mashima](https://anilist.co/staff/96882)'s assistant on Rave Master and Fairy Tail. In 2005, she released the comedy one-shot Flunk Punk Rumble in Shonen Magazine Wonder, which was later made into a short series and eventually publicized in Kodansha's Weekly Shounen Magazine from 2006–2011, with a total of 211 chapters. In 2012, she released Yamada-kun and the Seven Witches, which has to date sold over 3 million copies, and was adapted into a live-action drama series and a TV anime series. In 2015, Yoshikawa attended Anime Expo as a guest.
